messageBody:
On 11/30/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
>
>
> Agreed for this example. In general the errormessage will be clearer
> with the assertThat aproach:
>
>
> assertThat("hello world", is.containing("www"));
>
> will fail with
>
> ASSERTION FAILED!
> <HelloWorld> does not pass the constraint <contains(<www>)>
>
> while
>
> assertTrue("HelloWorld".contains("www"));
>
> fails with:
> junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> at test.TestSomething.testTest2(TestSomething.java:11)


Yes: producing better error messages is definitely one of the advantages of
literate assertions over traditional ones.

The only way to obtain the same result with regular assertions is to add a
string message, but we all know that if the developer has to do this
herself, she won't (I know I don't). Besides, it really does seem silly to
have to repeat this information, since the code already knows exactly what
part of the assertion went wrong. Trying to salvage this information in
order to present it to the user is definitely a laudable goal.

--
